input: Question: Tell me a bio of Jessie Mae Brown Beavers.
output:
Jessie Mae Brown Beavers, (March 23, 1912 – April 10, 1998) was an African-American historian, professor, and pioneer in the creation of Pan-African and Africana studies and professional institutions for black people in academia.

Beavers was born in Winston-Salem, North Carolina and grew up in Raleigh, North Carolina. Following the completion of her studies at Duke University, she taught at North Carolina A&T State University for 35 years, during which time she played a major role in the development of the African studies program. She also served as the program's first black female chair.

In 1983, Beavers was honored when she was named a Charles E. Howard Fellow by the American Council of Learned Societies. In 1990, she was awarded the Spingarn Medal, which is considered the "Oscar of the black academic community".

In 1994, Beavers founded the Institute for African American Policy Studies, now known as the Institute for African American Affairs.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Daniel Alexander Cameron.
output:
Daniel Alexander Cameron, sometimes known as Alexander Cameron or D.A. Cameron (his middle name), was born on August 16, 1813 in the North Castle area of Scotland. He was the son of Alexander Cameron and Margaret McNaughton.

In 1829, Daniel enrolled in the Royal Military College at Woolwich, where he studied under the tutelage of William Macqueen. In 1832, Cameron transferred to the Royal Military Academy, where he studied under Sir William Robert Warre. He graduated from the Academy in 1835 and was commissioned into the 95th Regiment of Foot.

In 1838, Cameron left England for Australia, arriving in Sydney on February 28 of that year. He was stationed at Windsor, New South Wales, before being transferred to Brisbane in 1841. In 1842, Cameron was transferred to Sydney, where he would remain until 1844. Cameron left New South Wales for Hobart, Tasmania in 1844 and, following the establishment of its colonial government, was made the colony's first secretary for public works.

Cameron returned to Sydney in 1847 and took up an appointment as the colony's colonial secretary. He returned to Tasmania later that year to become the colony's second governor. Cameron returned to Sydney in 1849 and, later that year, took up the position of colonial secretary for New South Wales. In 1850, he was made a companion of the New South Wales Legislative Council. Cameron returned to Hobart in 1852 and briefly held roles in the public service before being elected to the Tasmanian Legislative Council in 1853. He held several ministerial posts in the Council before being elected its president in 1859. Cameron resigned from the Council in 1864.

Cameron returned to the public service following his retirement from politics and was appointed chairman of the New South Wales Legislative Council enquiry committee. He was also made a member of the New South Wales Legislative Council. Cameron died on August 3, 1875 and was buried at the Hobart Cemetery.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Margaret Rose Vendryes.
output:
Margaret Rose Vendryes (born Margaret Rose Smith; July 10, 1914 – December 24, 2009) was an American plant physiologist. She was known for her research on plant hormone signal transduction and the effects of plant hormones on human health. She was the first woman president of the American Phytopathological Society and was a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

Vendryes was born in Decatur, Illinois, and earned her bachelor's degree in 1937 from the University of Illinois. She married Louis Vendryes, a professor of botany, and moved with him to Northwestern University, from which she received her master's and doctoral degrees in 1941 and 1943, respectively. She began working at the University of Wisconsin–Madison in 1944. In 1947, she became the university's first female professor of botany. She remained at the university for the rest of her career, eventually rising to the rank of professor emeritus.

Vendryes' research focused on the effects of plant hormones on human health. In the early 1950s, she helped establish the Food and Drug Administration's Office of Botulism, which studied botulism poisoning and initiated food safety standards for the fermentation process. She also researched phytoplasma, a type of plant virus, and their effects on plant diseases. She became the first woman president of the American Phytopathological Society in 1958 and helped establish the society's journal, Plant Disease Reporter. She held the position for a single term, and later served as editor-in-chief of the journal from 1971 to 1973.

Vendryes received several academic awards and honors throughout her career. She was named a Guggenheim Fellow in 1954. She was a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, a member of the National Academy of Sciences, and a recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1978. She was also the first woman appointed to the Wisconsin Ornithological Society's Bird Banding Committee, on which she served from 1957 to 1963. She was a fellow of the Society of Woman Geographers and a member of the American Society of Plant Biologists.

Vendryes retired from the University of Wisconsin–Madison in 1983 and moved to Durban, South Africa, to work with the University of KwaZulu-Natal. She died at the age of 93 on December 24, 2009, at a care center in Durban.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Stan Marple.
output:
Stanley Robert Marple, CBE was an English Detective Chief Inspector with the Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Police Force, who became famous for his role in solving the murders of five people, known as the "Bognor Four" case, in 1939.

Born in Yorkshire, Marple came to prominence in the 1930s for his work in the Drugs Division of the General Investigative Department of the Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Police. On 5 January 1939, Marple was contacted by Detective Inspector Harding of the West Sussex County Police with information about the murders of four people in the small Sussex coastal town of Bognor. Marple and his colleague Detective Sergeant Thomas Watson travelled to Bognor to assist in the investigation. Marple quickly realised that the murders were part of a larger, more complex plot, and over the next few days he helped Harding and Detective Inspector Donald Swann of the Sussex Police Department piece together an intricate story. Marple's knowledge of the community and his ability to gain clues from seemingly insignificant details proved crucial in solving the case. 

On 10 January, Marple travelled to Bognor a second time, this time with Detective Chief Inspector (DCI) Charles Warren of Scotland Yard's Criminal Investigation Department, and they formally arrested 38-year-old Ronald Smith, a vagrant who was suffering from schizophrenia. Smith confessed to the murders and was tried, convicted and hanged for the crime at Lewes Crown Court on 24 April 1939.

The Bognor Four case was the subject of the 2014 British television series The Bletchley Circle, in which Marple was portrayed by David Bradley.

output:
Jeffrey A. Satinover is an American scientist, professor, and author specializing in energy and the environment. He is the Daniel H. Pink Professor of Energy at the University of Michigan, where he also serves as the director of the Laboratory for Energy Policy and Innovation.

Satinover is known for his work on the environmental impacts of energy production and consumption, and has described himself as an "energy gloomster". His research has focused on the greenhouse gas emissions caused by the energy industry, and he has advocated for a transition to renewable energy. He has also described fossil fuels as "the world's most serious moral hazard", and argues that subsidies for fossil fuels have encouraged their use despite their environmental impacts.

Satinover's research has been covered in popular media, and he has made media appearances discussing his work. His first book, Energy Without Fear, was published in 2004, and he has written several other books and over 100 papers. Satinover has held academic positions at several institutions, and has been a visiting scholar at the World Bank and the International Energy Agency. He has served on the boards of energy companies and non-profit organizations, including the World Energy Council and the World Resources Institute.

Satinover is a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and a member of the American Physical Society. He has taught at the University of Michigan since 1990, and his students have included several leaders in the energy industry. He has criticized the energy industry for inadequate response to climate change, and has advocated for the adoption of renewable energy and energy efficiency. Satinover was appointed the Daniel H. Pink Professor of Energy in 2006, and has advocated for establishing a renewable energy target at the United Nations. He has been critical of the environmental movement and its approach to climate change, and has advocated for a "more optimistic, pro-growth, business-oriented" approach to climate change mitigation.

Satinover was born in Brooklyn, New York, and grew up in Wyckoff, New Jersey. input: Question: Tell me a bio of James Theodore Bent.
output: James Theodore Bent was born on April 28, 1821 to a family of farmers in Richland County, Wisconsin. input: Question: Tell me a bio of F. Gwynplaine MacIntyre.
output:

The character was created by writer Eric Roberts and was portrayed by John Carson in the 1965 serial The Androids of Tara.

The Second Doctor, Ian Chesterton and Barbara Wright encounter Gwyn on a planet called Tara in the year 2276. The planet is under the control of the despotic ruler Laker, who forces his subjects to labor in the mines to fuel his ambition of taking control of the entire galaxy. input: Question: Tell me a bio of Carl Braun (obstetrician).
output:
Carl Braun, M.D. was an American obstetrician and gynecologist. He was born on April 7, 1912, in Trenton, Missouri, and died on November 1, 2002, in St. Louis, Missouri.
Braun was a graduate of the University of Missouri School of Medicine, where he was also a member of the Kappa Alpha Order. After completing an internship at St. Louis County Hospital, he served in the U.S. Navy from 1935 to 1937. He then completed a residency in obstetrics and gynecology at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis before joining the U.S. Army during World War II.
Following the war, Braun returned to St. Louis and established an obstetrics and gynecology practice. In 1952, he became one of the first board-certified obstetrician-gynecologists in Missouri. He went on to establish a second practice in Clayton, Missouri, in 1953.
Braun was active in numerous professional organizations, including the American Medical Association, the American Public Health Association, the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, and the Society for the Study of Reproduction. He served as president of the Missouri Medical Association in 1951 and of the St. Louis Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists in 1957.
Braun is the namesake of the Carl Braun Obstetrics and Gynecology Institute at Washington University School of Medicine. The medical institute was established in 1964 and is home to the Division of Gynecology and Obstetrics and the Women's Hospital at Washington University School of Medicine, both of which are affiliated with Barnes-Jewish Hospital.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Abdullahi Mohammad Ahmad Hassan.
output:
Abdullahi Mohammad Ahmad Hassan, sometimes referred to as Mummar Abdal, was born circa 1968 AD in the Somali Region of Ethiopia. In 1991, Hassan fled war-ravaged Somalia for Yemen, where he studied at the al-Furqan Islamic Academy. He would later study at the Middle East University of Aqaba in Jordan, and the University of Wales. 

In 2005, Hassan returned to Somalia, and established the Al-Shabaab militant group as a means of resisting the Ethiopian government's influence in the region. He has since been recognized as the group's leader, and has been indicted by the United States government for providing material support to Al-Qaeda.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Ivan Toms.
output:
Ivan Toms is a multi-disciplinary designer who has worked in the fields of industrial, graphic and product design. He is best known for his co-founding design firm, IDEO, and the book, Design Like You're Making Money.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Muhammad Qutb.

He wrote several influential books while in prison, such as Milestones, which would become a manifesto for the Muslim Brotherhood. He was released from prison in 1948, but was again arrested two years later and sentenced to an additional ten years. He was released from prison once again in 1954, but continued his activism, writing numerous articles for newspapers and journals, as well as founding his own group called the Muslim Brothers Cultural Society. He died in 1964, shortly after being released from prison a third time.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Tom Coburn.
output:
Tom Coburn (born Thomas Richard Coburn Jr.; September 18, 1937 – February 7, 2022) was an American politician and lawyer who served as a Republican senator from Oklahoma from 2003 to 2013. A member of the Republican Party, he previously served in the Oklahoma House of Representatives from 1976 to 1994 and the United States House of Representatives from 1994 to 2003. A conservative, he was the ranking member of the Senate Budget Committee and the ranking member of the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs.

Coburn was born in Duncan, Oklahoma, and raised in Levoy, Arkansas. He attended college in Arkansas, graduating from the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff and earned his law degree from the University of Tulsa. After graduating, he moved to Okmulgee, Oklahoma, to open a practice. He became involved in local politics and was elected to the Oklahoma House of Representatives in 1976. Two years later, he won a special election to the United States House of Representatives, where he served until 1994. In the House, Coburn served as the Republican Chief Deputy Whip and was a member of the Republican Study Committee. He was elected to the U.S. Senate in 2002. Coburn was the ranking member of the Senate Budget Committee and the ranking member of the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs.

Coburn's positions on fiscal issues earned him the nickname "Dr. No" from then-president George W. Bush. He is known for his opposition to federal aid for education and medical research as well as to gun control and environmental regulation. He also played a critical role in blocking President Barack Obama's nominations to the Supreme Court. He was considered for the Republican vice presidential nomination in 2008 and the presidential nomination in 2016 but never ran for public office again after his term in the Senate ended in 2013. Coburn was married to Carol Coburn (née Carol Coburn Campbell) and had six children. He died of pancreatic cancer in February, 2022, at the age of 74.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Michael Collins (astronaut).
output:
Michael Collins was born in Dublin, Ireland on March 27, 1929. He received his secondary education at St. Brendan's CBS, and upon graduation in 1947, he emigrated to the United States, where he attended high school in New York City. After high school, he joined the U.S. Army and served for four years (1953–57), including a tour of duty in Japan. Upon his return, he attended New York University, where he earned a bachelor's degree in 1960.

In July 1962, Collins was selected as one of NASA's original astronauts. He completed training in September 1963 and was assigned to the Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston, Texas, where he was involved in the management of the Gemini and Apollo programs. He participated in four space flights, beginning with his flight in 1965, during which he served as the command module pilot for the Gemini 12 mission. He conducted experiments in Earth orbit, including one that tested the feasibility of recovering spacecraft. He also participated in the first spacewalk, and he spent 18 days in space during the Gemini 14 mission.

In April 1966, Collins became the first person to pilot a spacecraft in two different spacecraft families, as he flew the command module Gemini around the moon in the Apollo 8 mission, which was notable for being the first spacecraft to broadcast live footage of the Earth as it circled the moon. He remained with the Apollo program through 1969, serving as command module pilot for the Apollo 10, 11, and 17 missions.

After his final space flight, Collins participated in the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project, where he served as the commander of the American spacecraft and was the representative of the United States. He retired from NASA in 1973. In 1982, he was named a special advisor to the NASA Administrator, and he stayed in that position until his retirement from the United States Air Force in 1988. He then worked as an aviation and aerospace consultant. Collins was married to the former Mary Elizabeth Houbolt and had three children. He died of pancreatic cancer on November 30, 2012, at his home in Houston, at the age of 84.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Carol Dweck.
output:
Carol Dweck is a psychologist and the author of the popular book, Mindset: The New Psychology of Success. Dweck's work focuses on the idea that our mindset or beliefs about how we learn and how performance is evaluated can have a powerful influence on our ability to achieve our goals.

Dweck's early research examined how people learn best and perform underachievingly. She found that people generally believe their intelligence or talents are fixed traits, which they cannot change. When these people fail to meet with success or expectations, they often withdraw from challenges or opportunities, blaming luck or external forces, instead of themselves.

In contrast, people who believe their abilities can be developed have a "growth mindset". According to Dweck, this mindset is "very adaptive in the long run [and] leads to higher levels of motivation, perseverance, and well-being".

Dweck's work has been covered by popular media, including the BBC, CNN, and TED. She has received numerous awards and honorary degrees for her research, including the 2011 AAAS David Perlmutter Award and the 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship in psychology. She was named the 2014 Distinguished Scientific Associate of the National Academy of Sciences.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of John Forbes Nash Jr..
output:
John Forbes Nash Jr. (November 28, 1928 – May 16, 1994) was an American mathematician and economist who shared the Nobel Prize in Economics in 1994 with Reinhold Robbin for their solution to the Nash Equilibrium, a solution concept in non-cooperative game theory. He was born in Manhattan, New York City, New York, to John Nash and Mary (née McDonald) Nash. He had an elder brother, Peter, and a younger sister, Joan. His father was a song-writer who abandoned the family when John was two years old. The family later moved to Princeton, New Jersey, where his mother worked as a waitress to make ends meet.

Nash earned his AB in mathematics from Princeton University in 1950, where he was a member of the Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity, and his PhD in mathematics in 1952. His PhD thesis, supervised by Fritz John, was entitled, "Functional Analysis for Physics and Biology", considered the first application of the newly developing field of functional analysis to physical problems in quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics, and electromagnetism.

From 1952 to 1955, he was a lecturer at Princeton, and from 1955 to 1959, he was a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). From 1959 to 1973, he was a professor and the David and Lucille Anderson Professor of Mathematics at the University of Minnesota. In 1973, he moved to Princeton, New Jersey, where he was the first Casner-Myer Professor of Mathematics at Princeton University until his retirement in 1993. He was elected a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1972 and a member of the National Academy of Sciences in 1976. He was also an invited speaker at the 1972 International Congress of Mathematicians in Stockholm.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Idi Amin.
output: Idi Amin, was a dictator who ruled Uganda from 1971 to 1979. Amin came from a village near Kampala, Uganda and began his military career in the British Royal Engineers. In 1962, he joined the 20th Special Forces Group, a unit of the British Army that was stationed in Kenya. Shortly after arriving in Kenya, Amin was accused of organizing a tribal dance in an Arab style that was viewed as incompatible with the culture of the Africans in the unit. Amin was court-martialed and sentenced to a year in prison, but was soon after assigned to be a military observer in the Congo in 1964. While in the Congo, Amin organized a mutiny of the Ugandan soldiers who were stationed there and named himself commander of the mutiny. After serving as a military observer in the Congo, Amin was transferred back to Uganda and spent the next several years working his way up through the military ranks. In 1971, Amin was named commander of the Uganda Army and began to purge the military of those who were not loyal to him. He also began a campaign to win popularity by cracking down on corruption in the government and in the traditional leadership. He released those who had been imprisoned for corruption and instituted new taxes on the public. He also nationalized several industries, which resulted in widespread protests and a military coup against Amin. Amin responded by arresting the leaders of the coup and executed some of them. He also arrested and executed people who were accused of being loyal to the previous coup but were instead supporting the protests. Amin went on a rampage of murder and torture that resulted in the deaths of thousands of people in Uganda. He also left the country without any source of income and was eventually forced to leave Uganda and went into exile in Saudi Arabia. Amin was captured by the British government in Saudi Arabia in 2019 and was returned to Uganda where he died in detention in 2020.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Cleopatra.
output:
Cleopatra VII Philopatris was a Ptolemaic queen of Egypt from 51 BC until her death in 30 BC. She was the last known living member of the dynasty of Alexander the Great. She was of Negro or Khoisan origin. She was one of the longest-reigning monarchs in history. She was known as the "Great" (rather than the "LAST" or "Greatest" of the Ptolemaic rulers) because she was the last of the series of powerful and influential pharaohs who made Egypt an important international power and influence in the Hellenistic period, following the adoption of Greek customs and language, the introduction of Greek mythology and philosophy, and the encouragement of local culture.

Cleopatra's father was Ptolemy XII Neos Dionysos, her mother was Cleopatra IV Tryphaena, and her siblings were Ptolemy XIII Alexander, Arsinoe III, and Ptolemy XIV. Cleopatra was married to Julius Caesar, with whom she had two children; Caesarion and Caesar. After Caesar's assassination, her stepson, Ptolemy XV Caesar, was declared Caesar's heir.

She was born into a period of great political uncertainty in the Roman Republic. In the Second Triumvirate, Gaius Julius Caesar, Marcus Licinius Crassus, and Marcus Antonius were the dominant leaders in Rome. Cleopatra's father Ptolemy XII Neos Dionysos was a suzerain of Rome, but was unable to pay his debts to Crassus. Cleopatra's mother, Cleopatra IV Tryphaena, was a younger sister of Sextus Pompey, who was married to Crassus' son.

Cleopatra VII was well-educated as a child, and may have met Julius Caesar. At the Battle of Actium, on 2 September 31 BC, Cleopatra was Caesar's prisoner. After her brother Ptolemy XIII Alexander died in 32 BC, she was the last ruler of the Ptolemaic dynasty.

input: Question: Tell me a bio of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
output:
Muhammad Ali Jinnah, (; 12 December 1876 – 14 September 1940) was a British-born Indian lawyer, political activist, and one of the Founding Fathers of Pakistan, who also served as the first Governor-General of Pakistan and the first Governor of West Pakistan. Jinnah was born in Bombay (now Mumbai), British India (present-day India) to a family with Urdu-speaking Muhajirs (immigrants) from the present-day Pakistan Punjab region.

Born into a family of religious Muslims, Jinnah studied at the Government College, Lahore, and went on to study law at the University of Cambridge where he was also introduced to the Indian National Congress. He returned to India in 1904 and started his political career. In 1915, he founded the All-India Muslim League to promote the cause of separate Muslim statehood under British rule. In 1917, he was appointed as the attorney general of the Bombay Presidency.

After the Indian independence movement gained momentum in the 1920s, Jinnah left the Indian National Congress and founded the Muslim League in 1917. He became its first President and worked towards developing its organizational structure. He led the Muslim League campaign for a separate Muslim state, calling for a "Direct Action Day" in August 1940. However, the British Raj chose to divide India into Hindu-majority India and Muslim-majority Pakistan, setting the stage for the two new nations to becomeestine independent from British rule. Jinnah became the first Governor-General of Pakistan and the first Governor of West Pakistan, serving from 14 September 1940 to his death on 14 September 1940. He was buried in the graveyard of St. John's Cathedral in Karachi.

Jinnah is considered one of the most influential leaders in the development of the Pakistani nation and the movement for South Asian unity. In his honour, the city of Jinnahpurudda in Gujarat, India, was renamed to Jinnah Bhagwati Nagar in 1977. A city in Pakistan was also named after him, and the cricket stadium in Thatta, Sindh, is also named after him. His birthplace in Bombay was renamed to Muhammad Ali Jinnah suburb in 1976.

output:
